text: the the more recent finding is this peer
effect uh where where you know we did a
study where we had people come into the
lab um to take a battery of risk-taking
and decision-making measures on a
computer and we asked them to come and
bring two friends with them and then we
randomly assign them to either do these
tasks by themselves um or to do it with
their friends watching them uh and we
had teenagers college undergraduates and
adults you know 30 or so years old and
so what we found in this study was that
the mere presence of peers doubled the
number of risks that adolescence took it
had um a 50% increase among college
students and no effect at all among
adults now uh this was really
interesting to me nobody had shown this
experimentally before although it's
consistent with the idea that most
adolescent R taking occurs when they're
in groups and with their friends so we
we just recently U my colleague Jason
Chine who's a neuroscientist and I just
recently took this experiment into the
fmri so we have the subjects uh with
their brains being scanned and they're
lined down in the magnet the computer
screen is in there they can do the task
the same
task we haveen them come with two
friends their friends are in the Next
Room their friends can see their
performance on a monitor that's in the
Next Room and their friends are miked
into the the magnet so uh on Q when we
tell the friends uh they say Okay Dave
I'm watching you now right um and we
compare people's performance on these
tasks when they know their friends are
watching them and when they know their
friends can't see them at all so they're
not even in the same room with them they
just aware of their presence I mean
they're not encouraging them to take
risks or anything like that because we
script what they're allowed to say and
we've just discovered we're in the
process of writing this up right now to
send out to a journal that the presence
of peers activates the brain systems
that are in this reward circuit that
we've been talking about in kids but it
doesn't in adults and so we think that
the reason that we saw the peer effect
um is that when you are with your
friends when you are a teenager it
increases the salience of the rewarding
aspects of a risky decision which then
of course is going to make you pursue
the risky decision rather than be risk
averse um so we're really excited about
this finding um and uh we we we are just
working on a paper this morning in which
we looked at um the impact of the
presence of friends on people's
preferences for immediate versus delayed
rewards and we have we're just doing
this in the scanner now but in in our
behavioral research we see the same
thing so we have a sample of 19y olds
and they they do this task it's called a
delay discounting task where it
basically measures how much you'd be how
much less of a reward you'd be willing
to take to get it now rather than
waiting okay um when the 19-year-olds do
this with their friends watching
them they make decisions that are
comparable to what 14-y olds make um but
when 19y olds do it with their friends
not watching them they behave like
adults and so again it's this impact of
peers on reward processing that seems to
be going on that may play a role in
understand risk taking so uh when when
we first saw you you ask what gets me
excited you know when we first saw these
brain scans we couldn't believe it cuz
it looked too beautiful to be true and
we peaked you know kind of early on we'd
only run you know a couple dozen
subjects and now we've done the whole
experiment and um it's it's just amazing
it it is held up so we're really really
jazzed about
